column1: -------------------[Behavioral domains and their descriptions in the literature]--------------------

column2: The mental faculty associated with overt movements of the body
The state or process of executing an overt movement of the body(other than sepeech)
The state or process of overtly speaking
The state or process of imagining an overt movement of the body.
The state or process of inhibiting an overt movement of the body
The state or process of learning how to execute an overt movement of the body.
The state or process of observing an overt movement of the body.
The state or process of preparing for an overt movement of the body.
The state or process of resting from overt movements of the body.
The mental process of knowing, including the integration of awareness, perception, reasoning, and judgment.
The act or state of attending by applying the mind to any object of sense or thought.

The mental faculty associated with knowledge of a system of objects or symbols, such as sounds or character sequences, that can be combined in various ways following a set of rules, especially to communicate thoughts, feelings, or instructions.
(Only used for experiments which do not fall into one of the following Language categories.)
The mental faculty associated with the part of language study concerned with letters and spelling.
The mental faculty associated with knowledge of the distribution and patterning of speech sounds in a language and of the tacit rules governing pronunciation.
The mental faculty associated with knowledge of meaning in language forms.
The mental faculty associated with knowledge of overtly or covertly speaking.
The mental faculty associated with knowledge of the rules for the formation of grammatical sentences in a language
The mental faculty of retaining and reviving facts, events, or impressions, or of recalling or recognizing previous experiences.
(Only used for memory experiments which do not fall into Implicit, Explicit or Working.)

The memory that consists of information stored and retrieved explicitly from the external world. This information is about a specific event that has occurred at a specific time and place. Associations are done with previously related stimuli or experiences in the formation, storage and subsequent retrieval of these memories.
The long-term memory of skills and procedures; is often not easily verbalized, but can be used without consciously thinking about it.
The memory for intermediate results that must be held during thinking.
The mental faculty associated with the art of sound in time that expresses ideas and emotions in significant forms through the elements of rhythm, melody, harmony, and color.
The mental faculty of forming conclusions, judgments, or inferences from facts or premises.
The mental faculty associated with how people process social information, especially its encoding, storage, retrieval, and application to social situations.
The mental faculty associated with knowledge of one's body.
The mental faculty associated with awareness of the three-dimensional expanse in which all material objects are located and all events occur.
The mental faculty associated with the system of sequential relations that any event has to any other as past, present, or future.
Any mental processes that qualify as Cognition, but do not fit into any of the other Cognition sub-domains.
The mental faculty of experiencing an affective state of consciousness such as joy, sorrow, fear, hate, etc.
An emotion of wrath or ire characterized by displeasure and belligerence aroused by a wrong.
An emotion characterized by distress or uneasiness of mind caused by fear of danger or misfortune.
An emotion characterized by a strong distaste, nausea, or loathing.
An emotion of being afraid aroused by distress, impending danger, evil, pain, etc.
An emotion of well-being ranging from contentment to intense joy (excluding humor
An emotion of characterized by a comic, absurd, or incongruous quality causing amusement.
An emotion of sorrow or mourning characterized by unhappiness or grief.
Any affective processes that qualify as Emotion, but do not fit into any of the other Emotion sub-domains.
The mental faculty associated with sensitivity to stimuli originating inside of the body.
The need to regulate blood pressure.
Awareness of pressure or distension in gastrointestinal or genitourinary systems, including the mouth, esophagus, stomach, bladder, anus, rectum
Awareness of one's heartbeat or a sensitivity of accurately detecting its pace or speed.
The need for the body's cells to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance with their surroundings.
The need for the natural suspension, complete or partial, of consciousness.
The need for the maintenance of a constant internal body temperature independent of the environmental temperature.
The need for liquid that causes a sensation of dryness in the mouth and throat.
Awareness of pressure or fullness within the ear.
The mental faculty of apprehending knowledge by means of the senses.
The sensory systems associated with the skin, including touch, pressure, temperature and position. (Excluding sensing pain, which should be explicitly coded as Somesthesis.Pain).
The senses of bodily perception associated with an unpleasant sensation occurring in varying degrees of severity as a consequence of injury, disease, or emotional disorder
(Only used for vision experiments which do not fall into Color, Motion or Shape.

The visual perception of the quality of an object or substance with respect to light reflected by the object, usually determined visually by measurement of hue, saturation, and brightness of the reflected light.
The visual perception of the action or process of moving or of changing place or position.
The visual perception of the quality of a distinct object in having an external surface or outline of specific form or figure.
The presaccadic change in visual sensitivity
The rapid eye movements used to redirect gaze
Distribution of cell density across cortical layers in the human primary visual cortex
Network nodes with high functional connectivity
An emergent property of multiple domain-specific processors operating interactively
Conscious memory for events and facts
Refers to general world knowledge about objects, words, people, and facts

Integrating external informations with internal goals
Associating items and their contexts in the service of recollection
Encode individual items and support familiarity-based recognition
column2: The perirhinal and lateral entorhinal cortices

column1: Process spatial context and play role in general contextual processing role

Fundus of superior temporal visual area

column1: Observe specific, meaningful hand movements performed by others
column2: Rostral part of inferior premotor cortex

column1: Recalling these* presentations during observation of an action
column5: * : Motor movement and their proprioceptive components are stored as motor and somatosensory presentations in motor and somatosensory cortex.

column1: The representation of the peripersonal space and the transformation of object locations into reaching movements toward them.The represention of movement in near extrapersonal space for the guidance of movements in dense space and  and the control of defensive movements in response to objects approaching the head .
column2: Circuit between ventral intraparietal area(VIP) and caudal ventral premotor area (PMvc)

column1: The performance of visuomotor transformations for grasping movements
column2: Circuit between anterior intraparietal area and rostral ventral premotor area (PMvr)
Circuit between the part of rostral inferior parietal convexity(PF) and rostral ventral premotor area (PMvr)

column1: The cognitive processing of information associated with the oculomotor system
column2: Circuit between lateral intraparietal area (LIP) and rostral dorsal premotor area (PMdr)

column1: Complex movements of forelimbs and hindlimbs
Contralateral forelimb movements including: defensive, hand-to-mouth, and reaching movements.

column5: Based on monkeys and humans experiments.

column1: Encoding and holding in memory directional information about reaching movements
Linking external stimuli to defense responses
